utterances: No.
Actually, no. The governor of Texas at that time was Bill Clements, who didn't run for reelection in 1990.
She defeated a very interesting guy whose name - who talked about rape - compared rape to women running in policy, should lie back and enjoy it.
It was Clayton Williams.
That's right.
But it wasn't - she didn't defeat an incumbent governor to be elected governor of Texas.
Thanks for the call.
Nice try.
Have a good day.
OK, so long.
And she lost to a guy named George W.
Bush four years later.
Yes, she did, the guy whose father had him born with a silver foot in his mouth.
That's right.
Mike.
Mike is calling us from St. Louis.
I'm off to St. Louis tonight, Mike.
Hi.
How are you?
I'm well.
Is the answer Jane Swift?
Jane Swift, former governor of Massachusetts - acting governor of Massachusetts.
She's acting governor, but no. She became governor when the governor of Massachusetts was appointed ambassador to Canada.
But she didn't defeat an incumbent.
I guess...
Being appointed ambassador to Canada is a little like being beaten in the primary.
That's right.
Thanks very much for the call.
I think, Ken, you may have to put some people out of their misery.
OK, well, the answer, as you well remember, was Ma Ferguson of Texas in 1932.
See?
The audience knew it.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Everybody, thank you for not all jumping up and answering so quickly.
(Soundbite of applause)
What do I win?
You win the no prize.
Thank you very much.
Thank you very much for that.
All right, we've got some other things in the news.
And of course, we're going to get into presidential politics and the polls later.
But there are some interesting developments in - we're going to talk about Senate races, too.
But interesting, on the mayoral level in the city of New York, term limits is supposed to be only able to serve two terms.
And apparently, Mike Bloomberg thinks that he can now buy a third term.
Well, he spent $60 million winning - or $70 million winning reelection in 2005.
He's very, very popular, very successful governor - mayor of New York, I'm sorry.
Predecessors Rudy Giuliani and Ed Koch both endorsed him, including - and so have the Daily News and New York Post, and The New York Times editorial today said that term limits were a bad thing.
But having said that, in 1993 and 1996, voters in New York City voted overwhelmingly to have term limits.
And so what he would - what Bloomberg would like to do is to do a temporary change in City Council law.
The City Council would pass a little waiver just because of his economic expertise, he could run for the third time.
For the emergency, yeah.
And look, after what's happened this week on Wall Street, he might need the job.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Right, exactly.
We'll see about that.
But you know, in 1940, Wendell Willkie put out a button, ""No third term and no indispensable man."" And there are lot of people who feel that nobody's indispensable.
But I guess in New York City, if anybody could make it work, it's Michael Bloomberg.
And he probably could get it rammed through.

And one of the things we're going to be talking about is the - well, we had the first debate and it seemed to have had, you know, landed without sending up clouds of expectations, clouds of recriminations.
It seems to have landed with both sides having behaved themselves fairly well, and both men acquitted themselves really well.
You're talking about the presidential debate...
Yes, of course.
Yeah.
And in some ways, you could say that's good news for John McCain because he was so distracted by his role in the bailout, he was talking about postponing the debate.
We thought he'd be agitated.
The expectation game had Barack Obama clearly going to be the winner.

I thought for that reason McCain did well, but again, if Barack Obama went into the debate with a lead, and he did, and he came out and nothing changed in the debate, and he came out with a lead, in that sense, it's a win for Obama because it didn't change the dynamics of the race.
And some people said this was John McCain's best chance.
This was the foreign policy debate.
Of course, the first, what, 40 minutes were about the economic situation, not unconnected to foreign policy but nevertheless not John McCain's real house.
This was his best chance, at least on the topics that were announced.
But we still have two more presidential debates and we have the vice presidential debate tomorrow night.
And again, stranger things have happened.

But as you said in the beginning of the show, there are some indications, the Pew poll that has come out and several state polls show that Obama slightly increasing his lead nationally and in key battleground states.
Well, we're going to be talking more about that, as we mentioned.

But also, as you look ahead to the next presidential debate - of course, Thursday night we have the vice presidential - but the next presidential debate, town hall style again, a technique that John McCain is extremely comfortable with.
Is McCain seen as a Republican?
I mean, obviously, people in Nevada know him from next door in Arizona, where he's got this maverick...
Right.
Yes.
But I think both of them looked very comfortable in last week's debate.
Barack Obama, certainly, I think his comfort level was there.

If Barack Obama's goal was to show that he was presidential - sounds like with John Kennedy needed to prove against Richard Nixon in 1960 debates - I thought he did accomplish that but at the same time, John McCain's knowledge of world affairs showed, as well.
And again, it was a draw but a draw may favor the challenger here.
We're talking with Political Junkie Ken Rudin.
You can read his weekly column, the Political Junkie.
